title: From Open-Vocabulary to Vocabulary-Free Semantic Segmentation
author: Klara Reichard (Technical University of Munich), Giulia Rizzoli (University of Padova), Stefano Gasperini (Munich Center for Machine Learning), Lukas Hoyere (BMW Group), Pietro Zanuttigh (University of Padova), Nassir Navab (Technical University of Munich), Federico Tombari (Google Zurich), ...
background: Semantic segmentation aims to classify each pixel in an image into specific object categories, and this paper presents a method that eliminates the need for predefined object class names, allowing for free-form input.
contribution: This paper introduces a fully automated pipeline for Vocabulary-Free Semantic Segmentation to solve the dependency on predefined class labels, achieving improved segmentation accuracy in various real-world scenarios.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Traditional open-vocabulary segmentation methods require users to specify class names, which can be impractical and limit flexibility.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves by automating the process of object recognition and class naming through Vision-Language Models, eliminating user input of class names.

key_innovation: The unique aspect of this method is its ability to segment images without requiring prior knowledge of class names, relying instead on generated descriptions from detected objects in real-time.
real_world_impact: This approach enhances the practicality of semantic segmentation in dynamic or unforeseen environments, making it suitable for applications where object categories cannot be anticipated.
limitations: The authors note sensitivity to false negatives in tagger predictions, which can complicate the segmentation task.

new_terms.Vocabulary-Free Semantic Segmentation: **Vocabulary-Free Semantic Segmentation** refers to a segmentation approach that does not rely on a predefined set of class names, allowing the model to generalize to unseen object categories.
new_terms.Vision-Language Models: **Vision-Language Models** are a type of machine learning model that combines visual and textual data for tasks like image captioning and object recognition, often leveraging large datasets.
